newsitem.title: USA: Republican moderates seek new plant, wildlife bill.
newsitem.headline: Republican moderates seek new plant, wildlife bill.

text.p: Moderate House Republicans this week began canvassing lawmakers, green groups and developers for ideas to revise endangered species protection in a bid to avoid clashes that blocked legislation last year.

"We're going about trying to explore ways to find common ground, a coalition in the middle of the ideological spectrum, which could come together and pass a bill," Representative Jim Saxton, a Republican from New Jersey, said.

He and Republican Wayne Gilchrest of Maryland organised an all-day Endangered Species Act forum on Tuesday attended by about 30 lawmakers and officials from green groups and industry, from the Sierra Club to Georgia-Pacific Corp.

Saxton said it would take strong public pressure to get lawmakers to craft a bill that could pass muster with both conservatives, who want to ease land development restrictions, and environmentalists, who want tighter controls.

"The way Congress is made up today, in the absence of a welling of pressure from outside of Congress, I doubt this Congress will pass an Endangered Species Act in this term," he told Reuters after the meeting.
House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who led Republican calls for deep regulatory changes two years ago, sounded a conciliatory note with House Republicans on Wednesday.

"We are for endangered species being saved, and we are for American liberties being saved," he said. "We're for the right technologies for the environment and the right opportunities for the economy ... and we're going to solve both."

Endangered species bills stalled this year in a battle between environmentalists and House Resources Committee Chairman Don Young, an Alaskan Republican, who proposed moves they said would have put plants and wildlife in greater peril.
Young has not committed to backing bills by Saxton or Gilchrest, although he was willing to work with them, said Liz Megginson, chief counsel to the committee.

Democrats and environmentalists who participated in the forum said it was too early to predict how the debate would evolve. "It's not clear to me whether the agenda is to involve the Democrats in the development of a bill or whether it is to develop a bill that is moderate enough that Democrats would eventually go along," said a Democratic aide to the committee. "Those are very different things."
